results.title: FaceApp (2017)
results.brief_description: FaceApp is a mobile application for iOS and Android developed by Russian company Wireless Lab. The app generates highly realistic transformations of faces in photographs by using neural networks based on artificial intelligence.

constellations_other.name: Transformations
constellations_other.description: Like many techniques born from the visual language of magic lanterns, the dissolve effect was incorporated into filmmaking and is still used today.

results.title: Face/off
results.creator_credit: John Woo, Christopher Goosick, Terence Chang, Barrie M Osborne, David Permut, WCG Entertainment and Douglas Reuter Productions
results.brief_description: Acclaimed Hong Kong action director John Woo has created a delirious mix of spectacular gun battles, furious explosions and breathtaking stunts. John Travolta plays driven but anguished FBI agent Sean Archer, who is using the full force of his anti-terrorist unit to track down the psychotic criminal Castor Troy, energetically played by Nicolas Cage. Thinking he has finally killed Castor in a spectacular airport shootout, Archer is horrified to discover that he is in fact alive but in a coma. Undergoing a radical face-swapping procedure, Archer assumes Castor’s identity in an attempt to discover the Los Angeles location of a nerve gas bomb due to explode. When Castor awakens from his coma, he retaliates by infiltrating the real Archer’s life and destroying any evidence of the identity switch. Archer is thrust into a nightmare, where he must fight for his life and his family. This cat and mouse thriller was written by Mike Werb and Michael Colleary. Music by John Powell. Edited by Christian Wagner and Steven Kemper. Cinematography by Oliver Wood. Also stars Joan Allen, Alessandro Nivola, Gina Gershon, Dominique Swain and Nick Cassavetes.

results.title: Face value
results.brief_description: Explores the lives of three facially disfigured individuals in a sensitive and moving series of interviews. Discusses the meaning of beauty, the value of physical appearances in society and the importance of every human being.

results.title: Face to face: dealing with conflict
results.creator_credit: Agency for Instructional Television and Educational Film Center
results.brief_description: Highlights the need to be aware of one’s limitations and to know when to say “no”. An adolescent girl at high school takes on too much work on the local school magazine and as a result her school work suffers. Unable to handle her poor examination results, she lashes out angrily and irrationally at those around her. Raises issues regarding the need to accept responsibility for one’s actions and to be assertive as opposed to weak or aggressive.

results.title: Face of the Earth
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film explores the origin of our planet’s outer layer, the why-and-how of its mobility. Through the use of well designed diagrams, the earth’s cyclical activity is clearly explained. Some unusual footage on volcanoes give added punch to an already absorbing subject. (Awards: Cleveland; New York). Credits include: Animation by Eva Szasz; sound by Larry Crosley, Karl Duplessis; photography by Bill Mason, Simon LeBlanc; music by David Green.

results.title: Face of the earth
results.brief_description: Considers glaciers, frosts, landslides and running water as examples of “wearing down” forces eroding the surface of the earth. In contrast are the “building up” forces as demonstrated by volcanic lava and buried sea shell fossils found in rock layers. Portrays the Painted Desert, the Petrified Forest, the Grand Canyon, Zion and Bryce Canyons as illustrations of spectacular geologic formations resulting from the unceasing war between the forces of nature.

results.title: Face of South Africa
results.creator_credit: Raymond Hancock, Errol Hinds, Malcolm Lomberg and South African Screen Productions
results.brief_description: By imaginative use of photographs, shows many facets of the peoples of South Africa. In youth, adolescence and age; at leisure and work; in joy, sorrow and excitement. Photography by Raymond Hancock with commentary and narration by Frank Secker.
